entry.title: Ruby ||= operator
entry.content:
This topic is talked about ruby ||= and || operator It is always confused with ruby newbie

||= will set the left-hand value to the right hand value only if the left-hand value is falsey OR undefined.

Example 1, if a is defined as 4, using a ||= 5 will still output 4

``` ruby

a = 4 => 4 a ||= 5 => 4 ```

Example 2, if b is undefined

``` ruby

b ||= 5 => 5 ```

Example 3, if c is false ``` ruby

c = false => false c ||= 8 => 8 ```

Example 4, if d is true ``` ruby

d = true => true d ||= 9 => true ```

|| operator if left hand side is false/nil, it will evaluate to right hand side

```ruby

a = 6 || 4 # 6 is true => 6 a = false || 4 # false is false => 4 a = true || 4 # true is true => true a = nil || 4 # nil will also treat to right hand side => 4 a = banana || 4 # except undefined NameError: undefined local variable or method `banana' for main:Object

from (irb):26

```

I wish you can find it useful
